title: Easy Ways to Set Up a Fingerprint Scanner on Your Computer

steps.title: Check if your computer already has a fingerprint scanner.
steps.content: Check if your computer already has a fingerprint scanner. Many computers and laptops come with a fingerprint scanner already installed. The location differs from one laptop or computer model to the next. The fingerprint scanner is usually near the keyboard. It may be located on the palm rest area below the keyboard, or integrated into the Power button or the touchpad. You can also check the sides of your computer to see if you can find a fingerprint scanner. Some Mac computers have a fingerprint scanner built into the Magic Mouse.

steps.title: Purchase a fingerprint scanner.
steps.content: Purchase a fingerprint scanner. If your computer doesn't have a fingerprint scanner (or it's not working), you can purchase fingerprint scanners online or from an electronics or computer store. Fingerprint scanners range in price. For example, this Digital Persona desktop fingerprint scanner goes for about $80 and sits on your desk next to your computer. You can also purchase a mini-USB fingerprint scanner for about $25, which is compact and barely extends beyond your USB port.

steps.title: Connect the fingerprint scanner to a USB port.
steps.content: Connect the fingerprint scanner to a USB port. You can use any free USB port on your computer. Most fingerprint scanners will be ready to use automatically after you connect them (or within a minute or two).

steps.title: Download the drivers if necessary.
steps.content: Download the drivers if necessary. Most modern USB devices are plug-and-play, meaning the drivers will download automatically when you connect them. However, it may take a minute for this to happen. If the drivers don't download automatically, you may need to download the drivers from the manufacturer's website. If your fingerprint scanner comes with a CD or USB drive, you can use this to install the drivers for your device. Insert the CD or USB drive and follow the prompts to install the driver. If you need to install the drivers for your computer's fingerprint scanner, you can do so from the manufacturer's website for your PC. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Settings menu .
steps.content: Open the Settings menu . You can register a fingerprint using Windows Hello on both Windows 10 and 11. To get started, open the Settings menu. Use the following steps to do so: Click the Windows Start menu. Click the Settings/Gear icon.

steps.title: Click Accounts.
steps.content: Click Accounts . On Windows 11, it's in the menu bar to the left. On Windows 10, it's below the icon that resembles a person.

steps.title: Click Sign In Options.
steps.content: Click Sign In Options . On Windows 11, it's below "Account Settings" next to an icon that resembles a key. You may need to scroll down. On Windows 10, it's below "Accounts" in the menu bar to the left.

steps.title: Click Fingerprint Recognition (Windows Hello).
steps.content: Click Fingerprint Recognition (Windows Hello) . It's next to an icon that resembles a fingerprint. On Windows 10, this option will say Windows Hello Fingerprint instead. You will see a "Set up" button appear below this option.

steps.title: Click Set Up followed by Get Started.
steps.content: Click Set Up followed by Get Started . When you see the button that says "Set up" appear, click it. You will see a pop-up window that will walk you through the steps of registering a fingerprint. Click Get Started at the bottom of the window.

steps.title: Enter your Windows PIN or password.
steps.content: Enter your Windows PIN or password. You may be asked to verify your identity by entering your Windows PIN or password. Go ahead and do so when prompted.

steps.title: Touch or swipe the fingerprint scanner multiple times.
steps.content: Touch or swipe the fingerprint scanner multiple times. You will need to touch the scanner multiple times and at different angles. Follow the prompts on-screen and continue to touch the fingerprint scanner until the fingerprint icon on-screen is completely filled in.

steps.title: Click Add another finger or Close.
steps.content: Click Add another finger or Close . If you wish to add any additional fingers, click Add another finger and follow the prompts on-screen to add an additional finger. If you are done adding all the fingerprints you want to add, click Close . You can now use your fingerprint to log in to Windows as well as log in at various websites and applications. steps.title: Open the System Settings menu.
steps.content: Open the System Settings menu. You can add a fingerprint using TouchID on Mac computers and laptops. You can set it up in the Settings menu. Use the following steps to open the System Settings menu. Click the Apple icon in the menu bar at the top. Click System Settings (or System Preferences on older versions of macOS).

steps.title: Scroll down and click TouchID & Password.
steps.content: Scroll down and click TouchID & Password . It's in the menubar to the left next to an icon that resembles a fingerprint.

steps.title: Click Add fingerprint.
steps.content: Click Add fingerprint . It's the option that has a plus sign ( + ) icon. It's below the "TouchID" header. You can add up to three fingerprints per user account or 5 fingerprints per Mac.

steps.title: Enter your password and click Unlock.
steps.content: Enter your password and click Unlock . You will need to enter the password you use to log in to your Mac in order to continue. Enter your password and click the button that says Unlock .

steps.title: Touch the fingerprint scanner repeatedly.
steps.content: Touch the fingerprint scanner repeatedly. You will need to touch the fingerprint scanner multiple times and at different angles, Continue to touch the fingerprint scanner and follow the prompts on-screen until your Mac has captured your fingerprint.

steps.title: Select what features you want to use TouchID for.
steps.content: Select what features you want to use TouchID for. You'll see a list of options at the bottom of the screen. Ensure the toggle switch is enabled for all the features you want to use TouchID for. The options are as follows: Use TouchID to unlock your Mac: This option allows you to use your fingerprint to wake your Mac when it is in sleep mode. Use TouchID for Apple Pay: This option will require you to use your fingerprint to complete any purchases with Apple Pay. Use TouchID for purchases in iTunes Store, App Store, or Apple Books: This requires you to use your fingerprint to complete any purchases in the App Store, iTunes Store, or to purchase Apple Books. Use TouchID for autofilling passwords: This option will require you to use your fingerprint to automatically fill in any login passwords stored in your keychain. Use TouchID for fast user switching: If there are multiple users on your Mac, this option allows you to quickly switch users using your password.
